snippet: Gu Kailai, the wife of an ambitious Chinese leader, plotted to protect her son from demands for money by the Briton she is accused of killing, according to reports of the prosecutors’ case.
abstract: Prosecutors in the murder trial of Gu Kailai, wife of the ousted Chinese party leader Bo Xilai, say she plotted to protect her son Bo Guagua from demands for money by Neil Heywood, the British businessman she is accused of killing.

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG and ANDREW JACOBS
byline.contributor: Edward Wong reported from Beijing, and Andrew Jacobs from Hefei, China. Patrick Zuo, Mia Li and Shi Da contributed research. John Fisher Burns contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: Gu Kailai, the wife of an ambitious Chinese leader, plotted to protect her son from demands for money by the Briton she is accused of killing, according to reports of the prosecutors’ case.

headline.seo: In Detailed Account, Blackmail Emerges as Motive for Killing in China
headline.main: Blackmail Cited as Motive in a Killing That Shook China
headline.print_headline: China Murder Case Weaves Blackmail and a Mother’s Love
